description: Combat Application Tourniquet, produced by North American Rescue.  This windlass tourniquet officially in use with the U.S. Army is intended for stopping hemorrage in battlefield and pre-hospital conditions.  While not easy to use, it may save your life.  The strap is currently wide enough for use on an average adult's arm.  Activate to adjust size and location.

description: A roll of non-sterile gauze bandage, 4″ × 12 yds (7.5 cm × 3.6 m), produced by Cardinal Health under the Dermacea brand.  Used primarily to keep other, more potent wound dressing in place and under pressure, it can itself be used to stop light bleeding in a pinch.

description: A tiny piece of adhesive bandage with an even smaller gauze pad, produced by Cardinal Health under the Curity brand.  Intended for use with small punctures and cuts, it's ineffective against any serious bleeding, but still better than no dressing at all.

volume after trim (18.392 μl) * 1.4 g/cm3 = 25.75 mg ≈ 26 mg

notes: the result is rounded up to 1 ml, because 0.G stable does not support higher-resolution volume values

description: A roll of hypoallergenic cloth medical tape, produced by Cardinal Health under the Kendall brand.  Used to hold an absorbent pad or hemostatic wound dressing in place and under pressure.

A sterile 4″×4″ gauze pad, produced by Bound Tree Medical under the Curaplex brand.  Intended to be secured in place over a bleeding wound, using a length of medical tape or a bandage, to stem the bleeding.  Cannot be used on its own, since in doesn't adhere to the skin for medical reasons.
//weight: basic weight (density; 13.2 g/m3) × area of swab (4 in^2 = 16 in^2) × ply (layers; 12)

notes: weight_per_m2 is converted to weight_per_cm2 (g/cm2) in order to calculate over density (g/cm3)

//use_action: with nothing to hold the pad in place, it can't be used reliably as wound dressing
good-quality pads avoid sticking to the skin in order to not disturb the wound when the first-aid bandage is pulled away
